Lior, I appreciate your comments on the 2008 GDS tutorial.  To add on =
to Joel's response, you also asked whether there are more insights now into=
 novelty search than when the original paper was published.  Actually, the =
research in this area has continued and we have studied a number of more sp=
ecific questions on why novelty search works and under what conditions.  We=
 do hope to have these studies  published before long.  There are also a co=
uple new papers on the subject coming out soon that extend it in various wa=
ys, which you may find interesting.  So yes there will be more insights com=
ing and our understanding of the phenomenon is expanding over what it was i=
n 2008.

Several others have also made some interesting investigations on i=
t in recent years, including Jean-Baptiste Mouret's "Novelty-based Multiobj=
ectivization" (http://chronos.isir.upmc.fr/~mouret/papers/novelty_based_mul=
tiobjectivization.pdf) and our 2009 paper, "How Novelty Search Escapes the =
Deceptive Trap of Learning to Learn." (http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications=
/2009/risi.gecco09.html)

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "joel278" <lehm=
an.154@...> wrote:
>
> 
> 
> The basic concept of novelty search is to expl=
ore the space of behaviors in a particular domain. This is accomplished by =
rewarding individuals that display behaviors that are different from those =
seen prior in a search. 
> 
> In contrast, fitness-based search will genera=
lly reward individuals according to some fixed measure of progress. A signi=
ficant benefit of novelty search when compared to fitness search is that no=
velty search is not generally susceptible to the problem of "deception" whe=
re following the gradients of the fitness function lead to dead-ends in the=
 search space. Deception is the reason that fitness functions must often be=
 carefully crafted and tweaked in order to solve difficult problems.
> 
> I=
nterestingly, sometimes exploring the behavior space may lead novelty searc=
h to find the solution to a problem, though it was not directly trying to. =
Counter-intuitively, it may consistently be faster at finding the objective=
 than an objective-based search in deceptive problems.
> 
> Searching for b=
ehavioral novelty is different from an exhaustive search of the genotype sp=
ace for many reasons. As you wrote, many genotypes may map to the same beha=
vior; novelty search may avoid many of these equivalent behaviors because o=
nce that area of behavior space has been thoroughly explored, it will not r=
eward individuals displaying those behaviors, and will instead focus search=
 on variations of genotypes that are demonstrating more novel behaviors.
> =

> In addition, the domain itself imposes limits on behaviors; for example,=
 physics constrains our behaviors, we cannot walk through solid objects. Fu=
rther, demonstrating novelty may often require learning about a domain. For=
 example, to appear novel, a maze navigational robot may need to learn abou=
t walls and how to avoid them . In fact, this is what happens in the maze d=
omain explored in the ALifeXI paper. So, novelty search may be in some sens=
e about transferring information from the domain into genotypes.
> 
> An ex=
citing aspect of novelty search is that the search is open-ended and can po=
tentially continue endlessly finding novel behaviors that may grow in compl=
exity. While a fitness-based search may have little to do after it has solv=
ed a particular problem, novelty search can continue to find new behaviors =
even after it is has uncovered a solution.  
> 
> I hope that this addresse=
d some of your questions.
>
